conclusion: Consider properties of light waves and interaction with medium to determine diffraction likelihood.
Diffraction occurs when a wave encounters an obstacle or passes through an opening smaller than its wavelength.
Diffraction is more pronounced for waves with shorter wavelengths due to higher spatial frequencies.
Frequency of light is inversely proportional to its wavelength in a given medium.
Speed of light in vacuum is constant; higher frequency implies shorter wavelength.
Light beam b has a higher frequency than light beam a, so wavelength of b is shorter than a.
Shorter wavelength of light beam b makes it more likely to exhibit diffraction.
Light beam b is more likely to exhibit diffraction than light beam a.
